Award.AwardTitle: RET in Engineering and Computer Science Site: Research to Inspire Students about Engineering (RISE) through Inquiry

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding for a three year standard award to support a Research Experiences for Teachers (RET) in Engineering and Computer Science Site program at the University of New Hampshire (UNH) entitled, "RET in Engineering and Computer Science Site: Research to Inspire Students about Engineering (RISE) through Inquiry", under the direction of Dr. Brad Kinsey.

The major objectives of this program are to strengthen STEM learning and motivation and to promote engineering by:
-Providing pre- and in-service middle and high school teacher-leaders with an intensive summer research experience in an engineering field.
-Creating a community of educators, including teacher-leaders, faculty members, and university students, with research experience and teaching knowledge to assist one another as they develop and implement inquiry-based engineering activities.
-Providing access to equipment and materials for inquiry-based learning modules through the established UNH Advancing Science Program.

To accomplish these objectives RISE will create an effective and sustainable infrastructure to support RET opportunities at UNH for teachers throughout New Hampshire. During each summer of the project a cohort of twelve in-service and five pre-service teachers will participate in a seven week experience which will include orientation, intensive research, and curriculum development. School year follow-up to support the integration of the summer research experience and inquiry-based activities within the curriculum will also be provided, both in person with classroom visits by RET faculty and graduate/undergraduate students and through an electronic discussion board. The UNH Leitzel Center, which is well known in the region for facilitating exemplary teacher development activities, will provide the administrative structure for all project activities. Inquiry was selected as the theme for this proposal due to the expertise of the Leitzel Center in this area and the focus on inquiry based learning at UNH.

The broader impacts of RISE include the creation of a sustainable community of educators, including teachers and faculty, to collaborate on developing and implementing inquiry-based activities in classrooms. Participating UNH faculty and graduate students will experience the teachers' perspectives in designing learning activities that engage a variety of student learners. In addition, the inclusion of rural and urban communities and women faculty members as mentors will attract underrepresented individuals to engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF Research Experiences for Teachers in Engineering program supported the University of New Hampshire’s (UNH) Research to Inspire Students in Engineering (RISE). The country needs more students to embark upon engineering careers to fill the workforce demand created by loss of engineers retiring from the workforce and by new and innovative 21st Century industries. Engineering careers are characterized by high worker demand and secure salaries. Inspiring the next generation of engineers relies on our K-12 teachers to provide engaging activities and lessons that reach the diverse students they serve.

The goals of RISE were to provide teachers from diverse disciplines within science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) meaningful and authentic research training experiences in university engineering laboratories. These types of research experiences are critical to develop teachers own science and engineering identities, so they can bring valuable experiences to their students in their classroom students. RISE was a 7-10 week summer research program, where pre-service and in-service teachers performed full-time engineering research as part of a university team that included faculty, technicians, and graduate students. Through the course of the project, 57 teachers from schools in four states (NH, ME, MA, and CT) contributed to research projects through RISE. All teachers produced an engineering research poster that documented and communicated their outcomes of their research experience.

After the Summer research is completed, the teachers use their research training to enhance their own teaching lessons and units. Their lesson plans include the various aspects of the inquiry cycle where students ask their own engineering questions, design their own engineering experiments, collect their own engineering data, analyze their own engineering results, and report their own engineering findings to others. In this way, RISE helps to bring research and inquiry and the fun of discovery to students in K-12 classrooms.

In addition to the research experience gained by the teachers, they also develop strong collegial relationships with the faculty and graduate students with whom they train. This has led to lasting collaborations and exchanges of RISE teachers and UNH engineers that produced co-presentations at professional meetings, and co-authored publications. RISE teachers bring their students to Kingsbury Hall, the home of UNH engineering departments, for tours of wind tunnels and wave tanks and to use equipment like shake tables and electron microscopes.

Most teachers served by RISE teach students come from high-needs schools or districts, where the academic proficiency of students lags.  These schools and districts can be found throughout New England, where they serve distant and small rural towns and villages or large urban centers. In either case these communities often lack resources for education, including direct access to programming at nearby colleges and university, to prepare students for STEM careers.

The RISE model brings research and inquiry into schools through its strong engagement and training with the teachers that see kids everyday. RISE teachers are better informed about how research training can work to develop science and engineering identity in their students and the teachers are better prepared to offer supporting experiences to their students.
